name: Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game
description: You've just unearthed the classic post-apocalyptic role-playing game that revitalized the entire CRPG genre. The Fallout® SPECIAL system allows drastically different types of characters, meaningful decisions and development that puts you in complete control. Explore the devastated ruins of a golden age civilization.

reviews.review_text: Where to start with this game...  'It's a classic' would be a good place to start, I guess. I have no problems say that from the outset. It's only taken me 15 years to get around to play original Fallout, but I can see without a shadow of a doubt why it's so highly regarded.   Before you play this game make sure to download the Fallout Fixt mod, which is a very comprehensive community mod which fixes a lot of the bugs, and more importantly the resolution for modern monitors. Without this patch you'll more than likely experience a horrible rainbow pixalation effect during videos and gameplay.   Anyway...  Fallout is a turn-based RPG series which offers you various ways to tackle the game. Do you want to be a stealthy person, creeping around, pick pocketing your way to glory? Sure, why not! Do you want to be a smooth talking kinda guy who can talk his way in and out of trouble? Go on, be that guy! What about a bookworm who can use his brain to solve puzzles. Yup! And of course you can be a mix of all three, as well as a gun totting maniac! YEE-HAW! For my playthrough I used one of the pre-set characers (Albert) who was a Lawyer in a previous life and was set up with high charisma and speech skills. This opened up different dialogue trees throughout the game, which was nice.   Anyway, I enjoyed this game - I enjoyed it a lot. The characters are great, the voice acting (while limited) was pretty nice (though it did give away who the 'important' characters were) and the story itself was pretty deep. The game starts, as always, with you the 'Vault Dweller' leaving your vault for the first time to explore the wastelands. You're tasked with bringing back a water chip to save your vault before everyone dies of thirst!  There's a time limit to this, which (for me) cast a sense of urgency. Normally in Fallout games (Fallout 3 and New Vegas) I'm guilty of just going 'WHEEEEE' and exploring everywhere and not really caring what I'm doing. Yet in Fallout there's no time to explore, you've got to save lives! ... if you want to.   You see you don't NEED to save their lives, if you don't want to. In fact, you don't HAVE to do much in Fallout if you don't want to. It's not a narrow pathed experience, you can pretty much choose how you deal with the events in the game (and the end game cutscene will reflect on this at the end). A lot of games claim to be an open experience, and the actions you take reflecting on the game world, yet here's a game from 1997 which actually does that. I'm not sure it even heralds that fact that it does this. It just gets on with being a pretty damn good game.   This brings me on to another aspect of the game - the many different branches of the game. People react to you differently depending on what you're wearing, what you're wielding, and what you're intelligence or charisma is. I find that amaizng now (in 2014), so I can only imagine how mindblowing it was back in 1997 when the game was released. The 'simple' graphics by today's standards shouldn't distract you from what is a very complex game. There's a lot going on under the hood of this game and at times perhaps too much. My eyes were really opened up to this towards the end of the game when I was struggling with killing a certain mob. I had went about it 'head on' and was killed a number of times. Yet, after a night's sleep I came back with a different approach, a more sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s approach and it was so much easier, and strangely satisfying. I had killed the guy and he had never even seen me. OK, sure the wastelands were plunged into another 100 years of nuclear fallout in the process, but hey... I KILLED THE GUY!  However, even with the Fallout Fixt mod, the game can be prone to crash now and again. I'm not sure if it's the game's memory file getting too big or a conflict with Steam Overlay (wouldn't be a first), but towards the end of the game (and a lot of different quest outcomes) it started to become slightly unstable. So save REGULARLY!  Which brings me on to another thing. This is an 'old school' game. It will not autosave for you, you must take control of your own save files. If you die you won't be taken back to the next/recent checkpoint... you'll have to load up from the last point you saved.  This was the only thing I didn't like, but in the end I learned to live with it and it made me realise how pampered I had become as a gamer. I didn't have autosaves and 10 minute interval checkpoints when I was a kid and I still played games all the time back then. Yet, here I am as a grown man crying about dying and having to go back 20 minutes in the game because I had forgot to save... a lesson in life this game has given me. Also, this game is tough. REALLY tough. Depending on how you build your character, or which character you choose. You will die a lot. A lot.  So in closing...  If you're looking for an old school RPG experience than I'd recommend giving Fallout a try. I appreciate at time of writing they're no longer available on the Steam Store, or GOG, but hopefully they return one day, as they deserve to be played.

War. War never changes. The Romans waged war to gather slaves and wealth. Spain built an empire from its lust for gold and territory. Hitler shaped a battered Germany into an economic superpower.  But war never changes.  In the 21st century, war was still waged over the resources that could be acquired. Only this time, the spoils of war were also its weapons: Petroleum and Uranium. For these resources, China would invade Alaska, the US would annex Canada, and the European Commonwealth would dissolve into quarreling, bickering nation-states, bent on controlling the last remaining resources on Earth.  In 2077, the storm of world war had come again. In two brief hours, most of the planet was reduced to cinders. And from the ashes of nuclear devastation, a new civilization would struggle to arise.  A few were able to reach the relative safety of the large underground Vaults. Your family was part of that group that entered Vault Thirteen. Imprisoned safely behind the large Vault door, under a mountain of stone, a generation has lived without knowledge of the outside world.  Life in the Vault is about to change.

Where it all started, Fallout. Before Bethesda got the rights to the Fallout series and gave us the wonders of Fallout 3, New Vegas, and 4, Fallout was owned by Interplay and Black Isle studios. The classic Fallout games (1-tactics) were isometric turn based rpgs with a heavy open world exploration aspect to them. Now, jumping away from the history lesson and back to the game at hand. Fallout is a gritty, post apocolyptic rpg set after a nuclear war. And it really shows, raiders, super mutuants, anything in this wastland can be a friend or most likely a foe. The game can be very diffucult if you don't know what to expect. Everything you encounter, from cave rats to the brotherhood of steel, can kill you. Here's some spoilers, so don't touch if you don't want the story ruined. Ready? Alright.    You're tasked by the overseer of vault 13 to find a new water chip for the vault, as the one they have has died and water is running low. Setting off into a cave and the huge wastes, you must find a water chip and destroy the ever looming threat of the supermutant army, led by the Master. Once you complete these tasks in any order you please, you return to the vault you just saved....only to be banished.    If you're looking for a long, difficult at times, classic rpg, you should turn to the classic Fallout series. A definite must buy for any rpg fan.

Released back in 1997,  Fallout  is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to  Wasteland  with heavy influences from the 1981 movie  Mad Max , this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just ♥♥♥♥ someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll ♥♥♥♥, so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.  Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real ♥♥♥♥ happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.  The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time.   The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way,  Fallout  carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in  Fallout: New Vegas . There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.  As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. A classic isometric cRPG, set in a post-nuclear war California. The main storyline itself is interesting but short. The best experience you get is from wandering the wasteland, completing side quests, talking to people about their experiences in the wasteland, and getting powerful weapons and armour. Places and towns vary from the bunker of the brotherhood of steel, to the 'Boneyard' (a ruined Los Angeles).  The exploration is done differently from the bethesda fallout games. Instead of a continuous world like the elder scrolls games, you travel from place to place on an overhead map, going into real time when you enter areas and towns, or when you encounter enemies, like raiders, super mutants, and other special encounters as you travel across the wasteland. It's different, as it makes the wasteland seem more empty and barren (like a wasteland should be). The range of locations is large, from pristine pre-war vaults, to ruined cities, to gothic cathedrals, making each stop in the game world interesting.  Character creation is the most complex in the series, similar to that of pen and paper RPGs. SPECIAL is a system which determines your base stats, which you build upon with a plethora of skills, optional traits (most of which have both a good and bad effect on your build), and perks, which you gain every 3 levels (4 if you have the 'skilled' optional trait), which gives you benefits in different areas. This game depends alot on numbers and stats, so choosing the right build and developing correctly is crucial.   Combat is turn-based, and resembles table-top combat. It's difficult, but you won't be constantly dying. No cover mechanics to be found here. But this doesn't mean the combat isn't complex. Your character build is very important, and your stats influence what kind of approach is best. A high endurance and strength character, who specialises in melee combat, will do well up close, instead of shooting from afar. Aside from that, you have lots of weapons you can use, from shotguns and sniper rifles, to rocket launchers and mini guns. Unlike Fallout 4, which seemingly gives you the power armour quickly for some reason, you can get it through different ways, such as repairing a broken suit, or stealing one, each way requiring you to be part of the brotherhood of steel. On top of that, you can harden your power armour, making it even more durable.  Interactions with NPCs are interesting, and tell you more about the wasteland. Your interactions with them are constant. If you insult someone, they won't like you, they won't give you a job or a quest, or may even call on hired guards to kill you. This may seem simple nowadays, but it was cool to have back then. Important NPCs are shown with animated faces, and they can vary from paranoid businessman, to mutant ghouls. Your acts in the wasteland will change your reputation, and this will affect interactions with NPCs, which may lead to certain benefits or disadvantages.  The atmosphere in this game is some of the best in a game to date. Gritty, dark, but with a touch of sarcastic and black humour, this game obviously draws influence from films like a boy and his dog, Mad Max, and books like a canticle for Leibowitz. It's art direction draws on from the 1950's vision for the future, with robots looking like something from forbidden planet than from the terminator. The humour is sparse, but well placed in characters like Harold, who despite living in an immortal agony, he can still make a joke or two. The music adds to this, each track a poignant, ambient soundscape of the area you currently, filled with industrial creaks, whining winds, and sudden crashes of metal on metal, emphasising the unforgiving world you must surivive in, instead of constantly hearing about 'Butcher Pete', or whoever that is. Unlike Fallout 2, you won't have constant Monty Python references thrown in your face every random encounter, but there are some interesting ones, like a random encounter with the telephone box from doctor who.   This game is old (1997), and it shows. The enviroments look nice and detailed, but still have that pixely look. The UI can be confusing and off putting, and things like quests and missions are marked with little detail (e.g. 'Find the water chip'), which means you'll have to remember the vital quest details. The combat is VERY slow, but can be sped up in the options, though this won't do much if you have lots of enemies to fight. There's no auto-saving, and you'll need to save often, or when you get killed, you'll have to load a save you made ages back. I must admit that I didn't fall in love with the original games, but rather, with the Bethesda-era ones. My first game in the series was Fallout 2 and while I LOVE older games like this, there was just something that didn't capture my attention like NV eventually did, which thankfully got me into the whole series.  That being said, after playing countless hours of 3, NV, and 4, I decided to come back and have another go at completing the originals, going in order. I haven't quite finished this game's main quest, in fact I haven't really even come close, but I have to say that these games are far more enjoyable when you understand the game's universe and decide to force yourself to be patient with an unforgiving game. Typically, I don't like brutally tough games because I play games for enjoyment rather than overabundance of challenge, but once you get the hang of it, the challenge in this game goes hand-in-hand with the choice and depth.  I will say that for a game of its age, it looks pretty good. However, my complaint is that because they went with the isometric approach, I find it harder to actually become immersed in the world itself. Instead, I find myself revisiting my childhood as I see images of 90s-era 3D in my head, trying to imagine what it would have looked like had they made it in first-person like Bethesda did with their games. I like isometric games, one of my favorites being the first two Rollercoaster Tycoon games, but for a semi-depressing, deep RPG with questions of morality, it feels lacking in the immersion factor.  Where the graphics are lacking, the gameplay and story make up for it though. I have to say I despise the combat system mostly because you're locked into a single decision every round, but the turn-based system does allow for far more decisionmaking and strategy in combat which is nice. I can't begin to describe how many times I've died in the more recent games simply because the in-the-moment decisionmaking pressured me into pulling off a stupid move, so the turn-based system helps prevent that. I don't care much for the random encounters either, as they get annoying when you're trying to travel.  The world itself is well-designed, despite the graphics being less immersive. The stylization gives a depressing, dark atmosphere of a ruined world, and there is something about that era of graphics/design that really hits you just right. The world isn't extremely open-world, but this isn't meant to be an open-world RPG. You use a fast travel type system between cities, settlements, regions and you're often interrupted by random encounters in the middle of nowhere. The larger cities/dungeons themselves tend to be split into several separate maps. There isn't a whole lot of variety in environment design but it doesn't need it. In general, the world captures you in a way you can't really describe with words, though not really by immersion factor.  The story is entertaining, and it's fun to be able to basically carve your own path to your endgame objective, as RPGs are meant to be. The story begins simply, but then begins to expand until you realize it's a plot larger than you could have imagined. It involves choice in ridiculous amounts, not to mention it tries to reaffirm the series motto: 'War... war never changes.' by showing that despite destroying ourselves, humanity is still its selfish old self, yet we also have the capability of goodness and love.  I apologize that this review was kind of scatterbrained, but I can't really do an appropriate review until I finish the game in its entirety like I have with the newer ones. Altogether, despite my complaints with this game and the original games in general, I do strongly recommend this game both for Fallout fans seeking nostalgia and for fans of traditional deep RPGs with a turn-based combat system. It's a load of fun, particularly once you get the hang of how it works.

Disclaimer: I have previously played Fallout 3 and enjoyed both the game and universe. That being said, I looked into the original games a bit before purchasing to see what type of gameplay it was.  The Basics: This game has a top-down view with turn-based combat. The game came out in 1997, so the graphics are starting to show their age.  My Opinion: I didn't care for this game at all. There are two big things that ruined the game for me: poor direction and terrible combat.  When it comes to quests, I would like some for of, 'the main mission/quest is in this general direction.' I want some idea of knowing how I can progress. I am not asking for the game to hold my hand. I actually don't care for games that hold my hand. However, I shouldn't have to look at a walkthrough to tell me where I have to go for the main story. It would be one thing if I didn't know where to find a side mission/quest. Sometimes people get lost in games, sure. You start out lost at the beginning of the game with no sense of direction in a cave.  The combat was the second issue I had. It's clunky and bland. Maybe I just didn't play far enough into the game, but it just felt sloppy and wasn't engaging. It didn't feel like I was able to do anything. You start off with all of your items, and weapons, in your bag. You have nothing equpped. Take a few steps forward and you are in your first battle. Now, almost every single game I have ever played has you start with a weapon equipped, or you fight to gain that first weapon. As I said, you have your first weapon, why the hell is it not equipped or tell you to check inventory? So after you either fail or realize, 'oh hey, I have a ♥♥♥♥ing gun that nobody told me about,' you finally equip it. Now you can fight rats and point blank range with a gun. You shoot, you miss. You shoot again, you miss again. Meanwhile, this rat is going to beat the hell out of you and you lose half of your health while shooting and outline of the rat around him.  Conclusion: This game isn't for me. The sloppy direction and combat are what drove me away. Maybe the game is too dated. Maybe if I had tried it a few years soon, I might have been able to enjoy it. The fact is that now I don't find the game enjoyable at all.  3/10
